title: Introduction to 'gggenes'
text: geom_gene_arrow() ‘ggplot2’ geom represents genes arrows. start end locations genes within molecule(s) mapped xmin xmax aesthetics respectively. start end locations used determine directions arrows point. y aesthetic must mapped molecule(s). drawing one molecule, numerical locations genes similar across molecules, almost certainly want facet plot scales = "free" avoid drawing ridiculously large molecules ridiculously tiny genes.
code: library(ggplot2) library(gggenes) ggplot(example_genes, aes(xmin = start, xmax = end, y = molecule, fill = gene)) +   geom_gene_arrow() +   facet_wrap(~ molecule, scales = "free", ncol = 1) +   scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set3")

title: Introduction to 'gggenes'
text: resulting plot can look cluttered, ‘ggplot2’ theme theme_genes() provided sensible defaults.
code: ggplot(example_genes, aes(xmin = start, xmax = end, y = molecule, fill = gene)) +   geom_gene_arrow() +   facet_wrap(~ molecule, scales = "free", ncol = 1) +   scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set3") +   theme_genes()

what: Aligning genes across facets with make_alignment_dummies()
title: Introduction to 'gggenes'
text: Often want certain gene vertically aligned across faceted molecules. make_alignment_dummies() generates set ‘dummy’ genes added plot ggplot2::geom_blank() extend range facet visually align selected gene across facets.
code: dummies <- make_alignment_dummies(   example_genes,   aes(xmin = start, xmax = end, y = molecule, id = gene),   on = "genE" )  ggplot(example_genes, aes(xmin = start, xmax = end, y = molecule, fill = gene)) +   geom_gene_arrow() +   geom_blank(data = dummies) +   facet_wrap(~ molecule, scales = "free", ncol = 1) +   scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set3") +   theme_genes()

title: Introduction to 'gggenes'
text: label individual genes, provide label aesthetic use geom_gene_label(). geom_gene_label() uses ‘ggfittext’ package fit label text inside gene arrows; see ‘ggfittext’ documentation details resizes reflows text make fit.
code: ggplot(example_genes, aes(xmin = start, xmax = end, y =                                             molecule, fill = gene, label = gene)) +   geom_gene_arrow(arrowhead_height = unit(3, "mm"), arrowhead_width = unit(1, "mm")) +   geom_gene_label(align = "left") +   geom_blank(data = dummies) +   facet_wrap(~ molecule, scales = "free", ncol = 1) +   scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set3") +   theme_genes()

what: Reversing gene direction with the optional forward aesthetic
title: Introduction to 'gggenes'
text: default, genes arrows drawn pointing direction implied xmin xmax. can override optional forward aesthetic, can useful gene coordinates orientation encoded separate variables. forward TRUE (default), value coerces TRUE 1, gene drawn pointing implied direction, .e. xmin xmax. forward FALSE, value coerces FALSE 0, gene drawn reverse implied direction:
code: ggplot(example_genes, aes(xmin = start, xmax = end, y = molecule, fill = gene,                            forward = orientation)) +   geom_gene_arrow() +   facet_wrap(~ molecule, scales = "free", ncol = 1) +   scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set3") +   theme_genes()

title: Introduction to 'gggenes'
text: can highlight subgene segments, protein domains local alignments, using geom_subgene_arrow(). works similarly geom_gene_arrow(), addition xmin xmax (determine gene boundaries), need aesthetics xsubmin xsubmax determine subgene boundaries. geom_gene_arrow() produce pretty arrowheads, long xmin >= xsubmin xmax >= xsubmax subgenes (subgenes break gene boundaries skipped warning). suggested usage use geom_gene_arrow() fill, add subgene layer :  label subgenes, can use geom_subgene_label(), works similarly geom_gene_label() major difference requires xsubmin xsubmax aesthetics (xmin xmax).
code: ggplot(example_genes, aes(xmin = start, xmax = end, y = molecule)) +   facet_wrap(~ molecule, scales = "free", ncol = 1) +   geom_gene_arrow(fill = "white") +   geom_subgene_arrow(data = example_subgenes,     aes(xmin = start, xmax = end, y = molecule, fill = gene,         xsubmin = from, xsubmax = to), color="black", alpha=.7) +   theme_genes() ggplot(subset(example_genes, molecule == "Genome4" & gene == "genA"),        aes(xmin = start, xmax = end, y = strand)   ) +   geom_gene_arrow() +   geom_gene_label(aes(label = gene)) +   geom_subgene_arrow(     data = subset(example_subgenes, molecule == "Genome4" & gene == "genA"),     aes(xsubmin = from, xsubmax = to, fill = subgene)   ) +   geom_subgene_label(     data = subset(example_subgenes, molecule == "Genome4" & gene == "genA"),     aes(xsubmin = from, xsubmax = to, label = subgene),     min.size = 0   )

title: Introduction to 'gggenes'
text: can draw point genetic features, restriction sites transcription start sites, geom_feature(), label geom_feature_label(). geoms take optional forward aesthetic indicate whether feature oriented , , direction (TRUE meaning oriented towards right FALSE meaning towards left).
code: ggplot(example_genes, aes(xmin = start, xmax = end, y = molecule, fill = gene)) +   geom_feature(     data = example_features,     aes(x = position, y = molecule, forward = forward)   ) +   geom_feature_label(     data = example_features,     aes(x = position, y = molecule, label = name, forward = forward)   ) +   geom_gene_arrow() +   geom_blank(data = example_dummies) +   facet_wrap(~ molecule, scales = "free", ncol = 1) +   scale_fill_brewer(palette = "Set3") +   theme_genes()

Standard geom arguments ggplot2::geom_text(). padding.x, padding.y grid::unit() object, giving horizontal vertical padding around text. Defaults 1 mm 0.1 lines respectively. align inside subgene place text label. Default 'centre'; options 'left' 'right'. min.size Minimum font size, points. provided, text need shrunk size fit inside subgene drawn. Defaults 4 pt. grow TRUE, text grown well shrunk fill subgene. reflow TRUE, text reflowed (wrapped) better fit subgene. height grid::unit() object giving maximum height text. Defaults 3 mm, default height gene arrows (therefore subgenes) drawn geom_gene_arrow().
